newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Advertisers welcome challenge to Greek toy ban.
newsitem.headline: Advertisers welcome challenge to Greek toy ban.

text.p: Europe's toy manufacturers on Thursday welcomed a European Commission decision to challenge a Greek ban on television advertising for toys.
The EU executive agreed on Wednesday to send a warning letter to Greece, urging it to remove the restrictions, which non-national manufacturers say discriminate against them.
"We are pleased that the Commissioners have agreed to take action to uphold the principle of a single market," said Peter Waterman, Chairman of The Toy Manufacturers of Europe Broadcasting Committee.
"There is no doubt that this ban was imposed for protectionist reasons and that it has damaged non-Greek toy companies," the TME, which has fought the ban for two years said.

Greece bans television advertising of toys to children during the hours when they are usually active, on the grounds that it is protecting their interests. The Commission gave Athens a grace period of three months to find a way of removing the ban.
The TME said that it was also ready to meet with the Greek authorities to find ways of reassuring it that children were not misled or exploited by television advertising.
"Self regulation would be better than sweeping government regulation in meeting Greek concerns about advertising to children and bringing it under appropriate control," the TME said.
"Self-regulatory systems based on detailed codes of practice covering the content of advertising to children have been successfully applied in many others parts of the European Union," it said.
The Commission was sounding the first warning shot in a three-stage EU system of infringement procedures.
If Athens fails to come up with changes the Commission could eventually go on to take action in the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg to force removal of the ban.
